stem: A patient with a spinal cord injury at T4 reports a sudden, throbbing headache. The nurse notes the patient is flushed above the injury level and has a blood pressure of 210/110 mmHg. Which action should the nurse take first?

options.text: Raise the head of the bed (HOB) to 90 degrees.
Administer the prescribed hydralazine IV push.

rationale.correct: Autonomic dysreflexia is a life-threatening emergency in patients with SCI at T6 or above. The immediate priority is to lower the blood pressure through gravity by sitting the patient upright (raising the HOB to 90 degrees) before attempting to find the stimulus or administer medication. This simple positional change can prevent immediate stroke or seizure from malignant hypertension.
rationale.incorrect: While hydralazine might be used if the BP remains high after positional changes and stimulus removal, it is not the first action. Palpating the bladder and calling the provider are necessary steps, but only AFTER sitting the patient up.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: Identifying "Raise the head of the bed (HOB) to 90 degrees." is a priority nursing action/finding essential for maintaining patient safety in this scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: While plausible in other contexts, "Call the healthcare provider immediately." is not the highest priority or most relevant factor in this acute scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: While plausible in other contexts, "Administer the prescribed hydralazine IV push." is not the highest priority or most relevant factor in this acute scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: "Palpate the bladder for distention." is a common distractor; it is either a non-specific finding or an action that follows more urgent stabilization.

clinicalPearls: Most common trigger for Autonomic Dysreflexia = Bladder distention (kinked catheter).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: When severe hypertension is present (SBP > 200), don't look for the cause FIRST; sit them up FIRST to prevent a stroke.

mnemonic.title: B-B-B
mnemonic.expansion: Bladder (check it), Bowel (check it), BP (sit them up).

reviewUnits.heading: Spinal Cord Emergencies
reviewUnits.body: Autonomic dysreflexia results from an uninhibited sympathetic response to a noxious stimulus below the level of injury. Monitoring for flushing (above) and cool skin (below) are key assessment cues.
